md:LocalizedInfo.md:Summary400: Feeling like they have nothing left to talk about after dating for only two months, Milo decides to break up with Molly and not hurt her feelings in the process. md:LocalizedInfo.md:Summary4000: Feeling like they have nothing left to talk about after dating for only two months, Milo decides to break up with Molly and not hurt her feelings in the process. Seeing himself in exactly the same situation, Neal says that he’s been asked to fire an ad salesman named Frank. However, when Neal gets a chance to deliver the news, he balks. Meanwhile, though he prides himself on being one of the first customers at Amir’s Chicken Oasis, Tyler is upset to find that Gibbs has become the restaurant owner’s best friend. Certain that he’s successfully broken up with Molly, Milo is surprised to find that she is still around. Wanting to make himself clear, he invites Molly to meet him at a restaurant where he plans to give her the news. However, when Molly accidentally trips and breaks her ankle, he ends up taking her to the hospital instead. Meanwhile, as Amy uses role-playing to help Neal practice firing Frank, Tyler resolves to show Gibbs that he can also get into Amir’s good graces. When Milo’s breakup plan comes up short again, Gibbs tells him not to let Molly’s injury undermine his determination. But once he comes right out and says that it’s over, it’s clear Molly is unhappy with the decision and no longer wants to be friends. After finding the courage to fire Frank, Neal is stunned when he announces that he’s leaving to take a new job. Finally, though Tyler’s attempts to court Amir backfire, it’s Gibbs who’s left wondering what he’s gotten himself into when the restaurant owner sets him up on a date with his gay son.
md:LocalizedInfo.md:OriginalTitle: The Good, The Bad & The Milo
